Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Determination of the Optical and Reactive Properties of Water Vapor of Relevance to Atmospheric Radiation, Cloud Physics and Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is investigating water vapor absorption of near ultraviolet (NUV) solar radiation in the atmosphere. The results of this research may help resolve a long-standing discrepancy between modeled and observed solar energy absorption under clear sky conditions in the atmosphere. This research combines laboratory experiments, field measurements, and modeling to investigate critically important issues regarding the role of water vapor absorption in determining the radiative equilibrium of the atmosphere.

The objectives of the project are to make laboratory measurements of water vapor near UV absorption cross sections and their temperature dependence at spectral resolution and intervals comparable to existing satellite/surface ozone monitoring instruments, to monitor water vapor near UV spectral absorption in the tropical atmosphere, and to evaluate the consequences of including this near UV absorption by water vapor on satellite/surface ozone retrievals and on models of atmospheric radiation, circulation, and climate. Field measurements will be acquired by piggybacking a UV radiation spectrometer on the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) project, the AERosols and Ocean Science Expeditions (AEROSE) field campaign in the equatorial Atlantic. A different partitioning of atmospheric absorption by ozone and water vapor could alter model simulations of large-scale atmospheric circulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas in the earth's environment and plays a dominant role in the atmosphere's radiative balance. However, little is known about its weak single-photon absorption in the near-UV region and associated atmospheric impacts. We constructed a cavity ring-down spectrometer with a bandwidth comparable to those of field UV spectrometers and determined room temperature water vapor absorption cross-sections at 1 nm increments in the 290-350 nm region. Water vapor displays structured absorption over this range with maximum and minimum cross-sections of 8.4e-25 and 1.6e-25 cm2/molecule. We also measured water vapor absorption cross-sections at 0.05 nm intervals surrounding major absorption bands. We provided field evidence to support laboratory water vapor near-UV absorption measurements and compared the estimated optical depth spectra of ozone with those of water vapor for the standard U.S. and tropical atmospheres. Our findings suggested that water vapor near-UV absorption significantly affected ozone retrieval from UV measurements, particularly in the tropical region. Incorporating water vapor absorption cross-section data into a radiative transfer model, we estimated that the energy budget of water vapor near-UV absorption was about 0.26 W/m2 for the standard U.S. atmosphere and 0.76 W/m2 for the tropics. Since it was not thought that water vapor could have near-UV absorption, the effect of such absorption is not currently included in radiation and climate simulation models. Our work on water vapor near-UV absorption is expected to change the paradigm in atmospheric measurements from UV remote sensing observations and how atmospheric radiation and climate are modeled.

We also determined the temperature-dependent near-UV absorption cross-sections of water vapor at 1 nm increments in the 290-350 nm range by using cavity ring-down spectroscopy. Water vapor exhibited structured absorption bands, with cross-sections ranging from 1.4e-25 to 6.0e-25 cm2/molecule at 283 K; 1.6e-25 to 8.9e-25 cm2/molecule at 313 K; and 1.9e-25 to 1.0e-24 cm2/molecule at 333 K. Our study results show that water vapor absorption cross-sections vary significantly with temperature. Therefore, it is essential to incorporate temperature-dependent water-vapor absorption cross-section data suitable for the specific atmospheric problems to assess the effect of water vapor near-UV absorption on modeling of atmospheric radiation and on ozone retrieval. For satellite-based ozone measurements, the Ozone Monitoring Instrument (OMI) TOMS version 8 algorithm uses the UV channel at 317.5 nm to measure total ozone absorption. We calculated ozone absorption optical depths at 317.5 nm on January 1 and July 1, 2020 for Miami, FL and compared them with those of water vapor using temperature-dependent cross-section data. Water vapor absorption at 317.5 nm accounted for about 7.7% and 18% of total ozone absorption for Miami at 12 GMT on January 1 and July 1, respectively, using the OMI TOMS version 8 algorithm. Results of our modeling study indicated that water vapor near-UV absorption in the tropical region significantly affected the accuracy of retrieved ozone levels. The estimated energy budgets of this previously unconsidered water vapor absorption were about 0.38 W/m2 and 0.81 W/m2 for Miami, FL at 12 GMT on January 1 and July 1 of year 2020, respectively, using temperature-dependent water vapor cross-section data. Absorption of near-UV sunlight by water vapor is naturally occurring but has so far not been included in atmospheric radiation and climate models. On the other hand, radiative forcing by CO2 is caused by anthropogenic perturbations, and it has an estimated magnitude of about 2.0 W/m2 in recent years. Water vapor near-UV absorption can play an important role in modeling atmospheric climate change.

In addition to water vapor study, we developed an enabling technique that uses a combination of in situ quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) and Brewster angle cavity ring-down spectroscopy to simultaneously determine ice film thickness (several nm to tens of nm) and optical absorbance for ice films formed from water vapor depositional growth on silica at cold temperature. We obtained average absorption cross-sections per ice layer for selected wavelengths in the 290-350 nm range at 263 K.

The completed NSF project has broader impacts. The project has directly led to the research training of two postdoctoral scholars and three (two female) summer REU students, one of whom was a minority student. This project enhanced the field's research infrastructure by developing a new, state-of-the-science technique to directly determine ice film optical absorption. The project also enabled us to develop collaborative partnerships with researchers working on atmospheric remote sensing and on modeling of atmospheric radiation. The findings from the NSF project were presented in conferences and published in journals and on institutional website. Resolving outstanding questions pertaining the optical properties of water vapor in the gas phase and on surfaces is critical to advance our understanding of the atmosphere's radiation budget, climate impacts, as well as cloud processes.
